E4DB160DBEA0458B9B7C38FC3C956EB7.description:
Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation
coefficient of a linear fit. ★

E9FFCEBFD4C24549AEB6AF554FF10BA5.description:
Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept
(constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data. ★

A1E9AB2F221A41E4B8254C8BE509EC6F.description:
Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear
association.

214628128E2847B1982A724C9E258E46.description:
Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing
residuals.

62BD6312FA29417CBD20077742A2E375.description:
Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve
problems in the context of the data. Use given functions or
choose a function suggested by the context. Emphasize linear,
quadratic, and exponential models.

867D96C7BBD440B4B60204E8A38517D0.description:
Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter
plot and describe how the variables are related. ★

87F8E45C0B5B4C5288DD4808EDA76CC2.description:
Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way
frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data
(including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies).
Recognize possible associations and trends in the data. ★

B6D0E6B3E2AD4645B6DF263C65A03662.description:
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative
variables.★

A2C80C4524504EEA9ED6EA286D96D718.description:
Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the
context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data
points (outliers). ★

1139FB4B0ED7425E9D6C27850E67C310.description:
Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data
distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile
range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets. ★

5A2E03A2F4764FCF886753FCD2056F65.description:
Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots,
histograms, and box plots) in a modeling context. ★

7732F0F8EA04479B8385848616CCEA2F.description:
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement
variable.★

11E4343F733747F980F67864DF553342.description:
Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function
in terms of a context. (A1 and A2)

5F24ED4E6152469A815591B16C69DC5D.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model.

0FDD27DEE10C43D3B148F4062FCD9919.description:
Use graphs and tables to show that a quantity increasing
exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly,
quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

631D5E9613FF406C8E0D5A99953F9D55.description:
Construct linear and exponential functions, including
arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a
relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a
table). (A1 and A2)

14DF52B6E8694B99B4E471B220DD46AE.description:
Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a
constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.

E8211DACFB3D442F83795DBA588844F5.description:
Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant
rate per unit interval relative to another.

3C5950F15A3046DC90ADE4F7C64DED54.description:
Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal
intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors
over equal intervals.

B7F67E4DD75C4E6F97942803DEC72D31.description:
Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with
linear functions and with exponential functions.

E1869B5C236947D68DB13E7D7D7F4071.description:
Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve
problems.

B2B0D98BB987437FA28B2BFC67244F8B.description:
Identify the effect on linear and quadratic graphs of
replacing 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) by 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) + 𝑘𝑘 , 𝑘𝑘𝑘𝑘(𝑥𝑥), 𝑓𝑓(𝑘𝑘𝑘𝑘), and 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥 + 𝑘𝑘) for specific values
of 𝑘𝑘 (both positive and negative); find the value of 𝑘𝑘 given the graphs.
Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the
graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from
their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.

B768F970AAA646C8907D101E6230454D.description: Build new functions from existing functions.

50A3A7017B5C45A492FA28ECE6F0F9D4.description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively
and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate
between the two forms.
Note: Interpret arithmetic sequences as linear functions and geometric
sequences as exponential functions. ★ (A1 and A2)

1C3EE8AB3C9F4C4DA3563FB7A29F98F4.description:
Write a function that describes a relationship between two
quantities. Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or
steps for calculation from a context.

6577ACC58DF34CEF8E09DB36ECFCA96B.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities.

3059A0E6059E497BA7F5BA6B7989458B.description:
Write a function defined by an expression in different but
equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
For example, use the process of factoring and completing the square in a
quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the
graph, and interpret these in terms of a context. (A1 and A2)

010F61277C63447483B5858D7EADF826.description: Note: b, c, and d, exist and can be found in A2.

8C1AD1201F8541EABA92D7B2C3462A6C.description:
Graph linear and quadratic functions expressed symbolically and
show key features of the graph by hand in simple cases and
using technology for more complicated cases, including
intercepts, maxima, and minima if they exist. ★ (A1 and A2)

A21FC924BA824622A6964350513A0F1E.description:
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key
features of the graph by hand in simple cases and using technology for
more complicated cases.

568BE122A3004AE1AB00CF2DDCD6E365.description:
Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a
nonlinear function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified
interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph. ★ (A1 and A2)

8F4029CB5E9348DA9320D1CAED0EB450.description:
Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where
applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes. For example, if the
function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n
engines in a factory, then the positive integers would be an appropriate
domain for the function.

0D1396043F844968B6E58390C6F0A9E7.description:
For a function that models a relationship between two
quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the
quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal
description of the relationship. Key features may include intercepts;
intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or
negative; maximum and minimum; and symmetries. ★ (A1 and A2)

0DDA29583C1648A1B8F660A8F76AF57D.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context.

65EE44B0452B4DF49B4BCDB917D1CB3E.description:
Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined
recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers. For example, the
Fibonacci sequence is defined recursively by 𝑓𝑓(0) = 𝑓𝑓(1) = 1, 𝑓𝑓(𝑛𝑛 + 1) =
𝑓𝑓(𝑛𝑛) + 𝑓𝑓(𝑛𝑛 − 1)for 𝑛𝑛 ≥ 1.

BA190639B2EC471BA0A3C7CE9AEE28BF.description:
Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their
domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a
context.

AFED0CDF38334BBDA8700FDC5676F21A.description:
Understand that a function from one set (called the domain)
to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain
exactly one element of the range. If 𝑓𝑓 is a function and 𝑥𝑥 is an element of
its domain, then 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) denotes the output of 𝑓𝑓 corresponding to the input
𝑥𝑥. The graph of 𝑓𝑓 is the graph of the equation 𝑦𝑦 = 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥).

04740917977F48C98940FB5BDE1C7218.description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation.

D51B488DD373485E91AAC3400E5068C4.description:
Graph and interpret (with the use of technology) the
solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding
the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set
to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of
the corresponding half-planes. (A1 and A2)

114E7FE8FC0346CAB28B976B00ABBA04.description:
Explain why the solution(s) of a system of equations are
the point(s) of intersection(s) on a coordinate plane. Find the solutions
approximately. For example, using technology to graph the functions,
make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases
where 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) and/or 𝑔𝑔(𝑥𝑥) are quadratic, exponential, rational, absolute
value functions, polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic functions. ★ (A1
and A2)

2A0D35736A234BC1831D0EFDE8488D01.description:
Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables
is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming
a curve (which could be a line). (A1 and A2)

C739B9BECDA84D0E91CA2F4D6446B2B1.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically.

B8AA82ED92CE407DB310605CCEF5A1F0.description:
Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and
a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically. (A1
and A2)

A3272FADEBC5496B819C7BD81AC8C222.description:
Solve systems of linear equations exactly and
approximately. For example, with graphs, focusing on pairs of linear
equations in two variables.

255E8552346A45A68D2FDF3E12AC03B5.description:
Explain how the strategy of elimination results in finding
solution(s) to a system of equations.

D501E7198F3C40C6A9D1F9EFBE84F6EC.description: Solve quadratic equations with real solutions using any method.

077638079EF74AD49649F04A3EFCA253.description:
Use the method of completing the square to transform any
quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (𝑥𝑥 − 𝑝𝑝)2 = 𝑞𝑞
that has the same solutions.

2CB6509C19CA4B5B97D9F4FDCC5A1EE7.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable. (A1 and A2)

E9182FF3B02E45858758C3F287F1BE50.description:
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable,
including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

242F29A0D37D4DE19D3C3D4721123328.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable.

8EAC180C63D2413887341979F9F350DE.description:
Solve rational and radical equations in one variable and
give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise. (A1 and A2)

F4F470D528734CB2852616C17E6AD51A.description:
Explain each step-in solving equations as following from
the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the
assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable
argument to justify a solution method. (A1 and A2)

C98E8D7B9FFE4545A662FA2F88670386.description:
Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the
reasoning.

B542A9A6EB7D42A9AAEB76CB6188E0A4.description:
Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by
systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable
or nonviable options in a modeling context. For example, represent
inequalities describing nutritional and cost constraints on combinations of
different foods.

68E01681D5E9402BA8473C29C2687EE3.description:
Create equations in two or more variables to represent
relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes
with labels and scales.

1FA7A0B6BEE944D4B70C6AA41B4CB185.description:
Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use
them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and
quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

3682D705AE5A406090CE87F5BBA7FE61.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships.

EDB14ACA1C2A46C2960A80AEEC2821DE.description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for
exponential functions. For example, the expression 3𝑥𝑥 can be
rewritten as (1 + 2)𝑥𝑥 to reveal the growth rate is 200%.

08C6442233C140A99C682CCB64272534.description:
Complete the square in a quadratic equation to reveal the
maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.

17BA9EFC6706447F993AC6B9561BE609.description:
Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function
it defines.

36C781CD97CE46D8A3DA8D45E82B99F9.description:
Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression
or equation to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented
by the expression. ★ (A1 and A2)

8E58579AFCDB469E83CB9D92C178D1EB.description: Write expressions and equations in equivalent forms to solve problems.

109EAD8F50B94D1A92AA15947111EF5A.description:
Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to
rewrite it. For example, see 𝑥𝑥4 − 𝑦𝑦4 as (𝑥𝑥2)2 − (𝑦𝑦2)2, thus recognizing it
as a difference of squares that can be factored as (𝑥𝑥2− 𝑦𝑦2)(𝑥𝑥2+ 𝑦𝑦2).

04ADE3319F2D4F8FB71C84BB65B900AE.description:
Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms
of its context. Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors,
and coefficients.

D2FF05888A1D4C2299A7A9102B57164D.description: Seeing Structure in Expressions and Equations

74C1EAA86B9D4942A0A64349E5B936D0.description:
Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on
measurement when reporting quantities.

3281C991F76D41F0AF305997CE22D380.description:
Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive
modeling.

2A3A7C663676419DB79ED3184D9099B0.description:
Use units to understand problems and to guide the solution of
multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas;
choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.
(A1 and A2)

DD215280D8E04185913F6853777FEF89.description: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.

70CA2445832C4527B7BAE0E5E7B24207.description:
Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is
rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is
irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

CDB4A659B11647B7A77C8B5673DC85CA.description: Use properties of rational and irrational numbers.
